titleStmt.title: The first and second partes of King Edward the Fourth. Containing his mery pastime with the tanner of Tamworth, as also his loue to faire Mistrisse Shoare, her great promotion, fall and miserie, and lastly the lamentable death of both her and her husband. Likewise the besieging of London, by the bastard Falconbridge, and the valiant defence of the same by the Lord Maior and the citizens. As it hath diuers times beene publikely played by the Right Honorable the Earle of Derbie his seruants.
titleStmt.author: Heywood, Thomas, d. 1641.

keywords.term: Edward, -- IV, -- King of England, -- 1442-1483 -- Drama.

div.head: THE FIRST AND SECOND partes of King Edward the fourth.

argument.p: Contayning his merrie pastime with the Tan|ner of Tamwoorth, as also his loue to fayre Mi|stresse Shoare, her great promotion, fall and miserie, and lastly the lamentable death of both her and her husband.

div.stage: Enter King Edward, the Dutches of Yorke, the Queene, the Lord Howard, and sir Thomas Sellinger.

sp.speaker: Dutchesse.
sp.l: SOnne, I tell ye you haue done you know not what:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I haue married a woman, else I am decesue● mot●er.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Married a woman? married indéed,
Here is a marriage that befits a King:
It is no matudile it was done in haste,
Here is a B●dall and with hell to boote,
You haue mad● worke?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Faith mother some we haue indéed, but ere long you shall see vs make worke for an heire apparant I doubt not, nay, nay, come-come, Gods will what chid●g stille

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: O God that ●re I ●de to see this day.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: B● my faith mother, I hope you ●al see the night too, and in the morning I wil be bold to ●ld you to the Christ●ing Gr●ndmother, and Godmother to a Prince of Wales, tut mother, tis a st●ing world.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Haue you sent Warwicke into France for this?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No by my faith mother I sent Warwicke into France for ●n other, but this by chance being néerer hand, and com|ming in the way I cannot tell how, we concluded, and now (as you see) are going about to get a young King.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: But tell me sonne how will you answere this?
Ist possible ●our rash vnlawfull act,
Should not bréed mortail hate betwixt the Kealme●
What may the French King thinke when he shall heare
That whilst you send to entreat about his daughter,
Basely to take a subiect of your owne?
What may the Princesse Bona think of this?
Our noble Cosin Warwicke that great Lord,
That Center-shaking 〈◊〉 of warre,
That like a Colum propt the house of Yorke:
And boare our white Rose brau●ly in his top,
When he shall heare his embassage abusor,
In this but made an instrument by you,
I know his soule will blush within his bosome,
And shame will sit i● Scarl●t on his Brew,
To haue his hon●r toucht with this foule ble●h
Sonne, sonne I tell ●ou that is done by you,
Which yet the child that is vnborne shall rue.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
●sh mother you are dece●ude, all true subiectes shall haue 〈◊〉 use to thanke God, to haue their King borne of a true Engl● woman, I tell you it was neuer u●ll since wee imatched wi●h strangers, so our children haue béene still l●ke Chickens of the halfe kind but where the rocke and the hen be both of one ●reede, there is like to be birdes of the game: h●re you mother, heare you, had I gone to it by fortune, I ●d made your sonnes George and Dicke to haue stoode ga|ping after the crowne: this wench mother is a widow, and hath made proofe of her valour, and for any thing I know, I am as like to do the deed as John Gray her husband was, I had rather the people praied to blesse mine heire, then selide me an heire: hold your peace, if you can see, there was neuer mother had a to warder sonne, why Cosin Howard and
Tom Sellinger heard you euer such a coyle about a wife?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: My soueraigne Lord with patience beare her spl●
Your princely mothers zeale is like a riuer,
That from the free aboundance of the waters,
Breakes out into this inundation,
From her aboundant care this rage proceeds,
O'er swolne with the extremitie of loue.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, auoid a womans humor,
If you resist this tumor of her will,
Here you shall haue her dwell vpon this passion,
Untill she lade and dull our eares againe:
Séeme you but sorie for what you haue done,
And straight shéele put the finger in the e●e,
With comfort now, since it cannot be helpt:
But make you shew to iustifie the act
If euer other language in her lips,
Then out vpon it, it is abhominable, I dare be hangde,
Say any thing it makes no matter what,
Then thus be wearied with a womans chat.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I, I, you are the spamels of the Court,
And thus you sawn and sooth your want●n king,
But Edward hadst thou prizde thy maic●ie,
Thou neuer wouldst haue staind thy princely state,
with the base leauings of a subiects bed:
Nor borne the blemish of her Bigamie.
A widow, ist not a goodly thing?
Grayes children come aske blessing of the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay I beséech your Grace my Lady York,
Euen as you are a Princesse and a widow,
Thinke not so meanely of my widowhood,
A spotlesse virgin came I first to Gray,
With him I ●ude a true and faithfull wife:
And since his hie emperiall maiestie,
Hath pleas●e to blesse my poore del●ed state
With the high Soueraigne title of his Quéene,
I here protest before the host of heauen,
I came as chasse a widow to his bed,
As when a virgin 〈◊〉 to Gray was wed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come, come haue done, n●w haue you ch●d ●nough, G●ds ●ote, we were as merie ere she came, as any people in Chrstendome, I with the mist●s, and these with the ma●es: onely wee haue no fidlers at our feast, but mother you haue m●de a sit of mirth: welcome to Grafton mother, by my troth you are euen ●ust come as I wished you here, let vs go to supper, and in Charitie giue vs your blessing ere we go to Bedde.

sp.speaker: Du●c.
sp.l: O Edward, Edward, stic and leaue this place,
Wherein poore Gllie King thou art inchanted,
This is her d●m of Bedtords worke her mother,
That hath be w●tcht thée Edwa●d my poore childe,
D●honour not the Princes of thy land,
To make the 〈◊〉 kneele with reuerence at her féete,
That ere thou dl●st e●pale with soueraintie,
The● would haue scorned to haue looked vpon,
T●eres no such differen●e twixt the greatest Péere,
And the poore sill●st kitching maide that liues,
A●ls bet wirt thy worthines and hers.

sp.speaker: Q●ee.
sp.l: I do confesse it, yet my Ladie Yorke,
M● mother is a duchesse as you are,
A Princesse borne, the Duke of Bedfords wi●e,
And as you ●no, a daughter and a sister,
U●to the royall bloud of Burgundie.
But you cannot so basely thinke on me,
As I do thinke of these vaine worldly titles,
God fro● soule my sinne as farre dcuide.
As I am farre ●rom boasting in this pride,

sp.speaker: Selling.
sp.l: Madam, she is the mirror of her kind,
H●d she but so much spleene as hath a gnatte,,
Her spirits would startle to abide your taunts,
She is a Sain●, and Madam you blaspheme,
●o wrong so sweete a Ladie.

sp.speaker: Duch.
sp.l: Thou art a ●nion and a slatterer.

sp.speaker: Sellin.
sp.l: Madam but that you are my soueraignes mother,
I would let you know you wrong a Gentleman,

sp.speaker: Howard.
sp.l: Good Cosin Sellinger haue patience,
Her Graces rage by too much violence,
Hath spent it selfe alreadie into ●re:
Déere Madam I beseeth you on my knee,
Tender that louing kindnesse to the Quéene,
That I dare sweare she doth in soule to you.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Well said good Cose, I pray thee make them friends, why how now Besse, what weepe? nay then ile chide y●u: what sodaine newes comes by this messenger?

div.stage: Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: My soueraigne Lord, the bastard Falconbridge,
Of late hath stird rebellion in the South,
Incouraging his forces to deliuer,
King Henrie late deposde out of the Towre,
To him the malcontented commons flocke,
From euerie part of Sussex, Kent, and Esier,
His armic waxed twentie thousand strong.
And as it is supposde by circumstance,
Meane to take London, if not well defended.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well let this Phaeton that is mountel thus,
Looke he sit surely, or by Englands George,
Ile breake his necke, this is no new euasion,
I surely thought that one day I should see,
That bastard Falcon take his wings to mount,
Into our Eagle airie, me thought I saw,
Blacke ●iscontent sit euer on his brow,
And now I see I calculated well,
Good Cosin Howard, and Tom Sellinger,
This night wéele spend in fe●st and ●llitie,
With our new Quéene, a●d our beloued mother,
To morrow you shall hau● commission,
To raise vp power against this haughtie rebell:
Sirra depart not till you know our pleas●re,
You shall conuey vs letters backe to London,
Unto the Maior, Recorder, and our friends,
Is supper readie? come by my bonnie Besse,
Welcome mother, we are all your guests.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge with his troupes marching, Spicing, Smoake, Chub, and others.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hold drumme,

sp.speaker: 1. Spi.
sp.l: Hold drumme and be hangde,

sp.speaker: 2. Smoke.
sp.p: Hold drumme hold, peace then ho, silence to the 3 proclamation.

sp.speaker: 1. Spi.
sp.l: You lie you rogue, tis to the Oration,

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Nay then you all lie, it is to the coblication,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: True hearted English and our valiant friends,

sp.speaker: all.
sp.l: Do braue generall isaith.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace there you rogues, or I will split your chaps:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: De are countrimen, I publikely proclaime,
If any wronged discontented English,
Toucht with true faeling of King Hennes wrongs,
Henrie the ●rt the lawfull King of England,
Who by that tyrant Edward the vsurper,
Is held a wretched prisoner in the Lowre,
If any man that faine would be enfranchisde,
From the sad yoake of ●orkrsh seruitude,
Under which w● toile like naked Gallislaues,
Know he that Thomas Neuill the Lord Falconbridridge:

sp.speaker: all.
sp.l: I &, a Falconbridge a falconbridge:

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: P●ace ye clamorous rogues, on General on with poor
Oration, peace there,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Pit●ing King Henries poore destressed case,
Armde with his title, and a subiects zeale,
Takes vp iust arm●s against the house of Yorks:
And do proclaime our ancient libertie:

sp.speaker: all.
sp.l: Libertie, libertie, libertie, generall libertie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: We do not rise like Tiler, Cade, and Straw,
Blewbeard, & other of that rascall route,
Bascly like Linkers, or such mnddle ●anes,
For mending measures, or the price of corne,
Or for some common in the wild of Kent,
Thats by some gréedie Cormorant inclosde:
But in the true and ancient lawfull right,
Of the redoubted bouse of Lancaster.
Our bloud is noble, by our birth a Neuill,
And by our lawfull line Lord Falconbridge,
Whose here thats of so dull a leaden temper,
That is not fired with a Neuils name?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Neuill, a Neuill, a Neuill.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Our quarrell like our selfe is honourable,
The law our warrant.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: I, I, the law is on our side.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: I, the law is in our own hands,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace you rogues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: And more, a blessing by the word proposoe,
To those that aide a true annointed King,
Courage braue spirits and crie a Falconbridge,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A Falconbridge, a Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: We will be masters of the mint our selues,
And set our owne stampe on the golden coyne:
Wéele shooe our neighing coursers with no worse
Then the purest s●iuer that is sold in Cheape.
At Leaden hall weele sell pearles by the pecke,
As now the mealemen vse to sell their meale:
In Westminster wéele kéep a solemne court,
And build it bigger to receiue our men,
Crie Falconbridge my hearts libertie,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Falconbridge and libertie, &c.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: Peace ye slaues, or I will smoke ye else,

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: Peace ye slaues, or I will chub your chappes, but indeede thou maist well smoke them, because thy name is Smoke.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.p: Why sirra, I hope Smoke the Smith of Chepsted, is as good a man as Chub the Chandler of Sandwich.

sp.speaker: Spicing.
sp.l:
Peace ye rogues, what are you quarrelling? and
now list to Captaine Spicing.
You know Cheapeside there are the Mercers shops,
Where we will measure veluet by the pikes:
And Silkes and Sattens by the streetes whole bredth:
Weele take the Tankards from the Conduit cockes,
To fill with Ip●ras and drinke carowse.
Where chaines of gold and plate shall be as plentie,
As wodden dishes in the wild of Kent:

sp.speaker: Smoake.
sp.p: Oh brauely said Ned Spicing, the honestest Lad that euer punde spice in a mortar, now speakes Captaine Smoke.

sp.l: Looke Lads for from this hil ye may discerne,
The louely towne which we are ma●hing to,
That same is London Lads yelook● vpon,
Raunge all arow my hearts and stand at gaze,
As doe the heards of Déere at some strange sight:
Or as a troupe of hungrie trauel●s,
That fire their eies vpon a fur●d feast,
Looke how the Towre doth tice vs to come on,
To take out Henry the sixt there prisoner,
See how S. Katherines smokes, wipe slaues vour eies
And whet your stomackes for the good mault pies.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Why then belike I am no bodie: roome and auoy|dance, for now speakes Captaine Chub:
No sooner in London will we be,
But the Bakers for you, the Brewers for me,
Bir●hin lane shall sute vs, the Costermongers fruite vs:
The Poulters send vs in sowle,
And Butchers meat without controule:
And euer when we sup or dine,
The Vintners freely bring vs in wine:
If any bodie aske who shall pay,
Cut off his head and send him away.
This is Captaine Chubs law whosoeuer say nay.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Brauely resolude, so m●rch we forward all,
And boldly say, good lucke shall vs be●all.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the Lord Maior, M. Shoare. M. Iosseline, in their veluet coates, and gorgets, and leading staues.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This is well done, thus should good Cittizens,
F●hion themselues as well for warre as peace:
Haue yee command●d that in euerie streese,
They h●g forth ligh●s as soone as ●ght comes one
Say Colin Sn●are that was referd to you.
●hoare〈◊〉 haue my Lord, besides from euerie hall
T●ere is at least two hund●ed men in armes.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 cheares my heart to heare this readines,
Let neuer r●bels put true Subiects downe,
Come when they will, th● welcome shall be such,
As they had better kept them further off.
But where is M. Recorder? his aduise,
Must not be wanting in these high affaires.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: About an houre agoe, and somewhat more,
I left him fortifying the bridge my Lord,
Which done he purposed to méete you here:

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A discreet paineful Gentleman he is,
And we must all of vs be so inclinde:
If we entend to haue the Citie safe,
Or looke for thanks, and credit with the King,
I tell ye maisters, aged though I be,
I (for my pa●t) will to no bed this night.

sp.speaker: Ioss.
sp.l: Why is it thought the Bastard is so neare?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How ●cane ye M. Iosseline by neare?
He neither comes from Italy nor Spaine:
But out of Kent, and Esser which you know,
Are both so neare, as nearer cannot be.

sp.speaker: Ioss.
sp.l: Nay, by your patience good my Lord a word,
Simple though I am, yet I must confesse,
A mischiefe further off, would, and so forth,
You know my meaning, things not seene before,
Are, and so forth, yet in good sadnes,
I would that all were well, and perchance,
It may be so, what, were it not for hope,
The heart, and so forth, but to the matter,
You meane and purpose, I, I, am sure ye doe?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well M. Iosseline, we are sure ye mean well
Although somewhat defectiue in your vtterance.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: I, I, my Lord Maior, I am you know,
Willing readie, & so forth, tut, tut, for me, ha, ha,
My Manston is at Ham, and thence you know,
I come to helpe you in this néedfull time:
When rebels are so busie, and so forth,
What masters, age must neuer be despisde,
You shall find me my Lord, still, and so forth.

div.stage: Enter Vrswicke the Recorder.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My Lord, now here comes M. Recorder.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Good euen my good Lord Maior, the stréets are chainde,
The bridge well manned & euerie place preparde,
Shall we now go together and consult.
What else there is to be determinde of?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your comming M. Recorder was the thing
We all desired, therefore let vs consult,
And now what say ye, if with halfe our power,
Wee issue forth, and giue the rebels fight?

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: Before they do prouoke vs nearer hand
There were no way to that, if all be pleasde,
Whats your opinion M. Iosseline?

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Good soo●h my L. Maior, and M. Recorder,
You may take your choice, but in my conceit,
Issue if you will, or else stay if you will,
A man can neuer be too warie and so forth,
Yet as to issue will not be the worst,
Euen so to tarrie, wel, you may thinke more on't,
But all is one, we shall be sure to fight,
And you are wise enough, to sée your time, I, I, a Gods name.

sp.speaker: Rec.
sp.l: My Lord accept his meaning better then his counsell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I, so we do, or else we were to blame,
What if we stoppe the passage of the Thames,
With such prouision as we haue of shippes?

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: Its doubtfull yet my Lord, whether the rebels,
Purpose that way to séeke our detriment,
Rather me séemeth they will come by land,
And either make assault at London bridge,
Or else at Algate, both which enterances,
Were good they should be strongly lortified.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Well said master Recorder, you do, I I, Iye warrant

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: As for the other, the whole companies
Of Mercers, Grocers, Drapers, and the rest,
Are drawne together for their best defence,
Beside the Towre, a neighbour to that place,
As on the one side it will cléere the riuer,
So on the other with their ordenance,
It may repulse and beate them from the gate,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What noyse is this? prouide ye sodainely:
And euerie man betake him to his charge.

div.stage: Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Soft who is this, how now my friend what newes?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: My master the Lieutenant of the Towre, giues ye to vnderstand, he hath descride the armie of the rebels.

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: Which may come they?

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.l: From Essexward, and therefore tis his mind,
You guarde both Algate wel, and Bishopsgate.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Saint George away, and let vs all resolue,
Either to vanquish this rebellious rout,
Preserue our goods, our children and our wiues,
Or seale our resolution with our liues.

div.stage: Exeu●t.
Enter Falconbridge, Spicing, with his troupes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Summon the Citie, and commaund our entrance,
Which if we shall be stubbornly denide,
Our power shal rush like thunder through the walles,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Open your gates slaues when I commaund ye,

Spicing beates on the gates, and then enters the Lord Ma|ior
and his associates with prentises.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.l: Whats he that beates thus at the Cittie gates,
Commaun●ing entrance as ●e were a King?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: He that will haue releasement for a King:
I 〈◊〉 Neuell the Lord Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Spi
sp.l: H● sirra, you, clapp●n, ●che, ●olt,
Or ●e bolt you if I get in, stand you preaching with a pore?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We haue no warrant I ho. Falconbridge,
To let your armed troupes into our Citie,
Considering you haue taken vp these armes,
Against our soueraigne and our c●untries peace.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I tell thee Mawr, and know he tels thée so,
That commeth armed in a Kings defence,
That I craue entrance in Kings He●es name,
In right of the true line of Lancaster,
Me thinks that word spoke from a Ne●ls mouth
Should like an earthquake rend your chained gates,
And teare in péeces your port●ullcises,
I thunder it againe into you eares,
You stout and braue couragious London●rs,
In Henries name I craue my entrance in.

sp.speaker: ●R.
sp.l: Should Henries name commaund thee entrance here
We should denie allrageance unt●Edward,
Whose true and f●thfull subiects we are ●uorne,
And in whose presence is our sw● vp bo●ne.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I tell thee traitor then th●u bearst thy 〈◊〉
Against thy true vndoubted King.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Nay then I tell thee bastard Falconbridge,
My Lord Ma●or beares his sword in his defence,
That put the sword into the armes of London,
Made the Lord Malors for euer after Knights,
Richard, d●osde . . . Henrie Bollingbrooke,
From whom the house of Yorke doth claime their right.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Whats he that answeres vs thus saucil●

sp.speaker: Smo.
sp.l: Sirra your name, that we may know ye hereafter,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: My name is Shoare, a Goldsmith by my trade,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What not that Shoare that hath the da●e wife,
Shoares wife, the flowre of London for her beautie.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Yes rebell euen the verie same.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Runne rascall and fetch thy wife to our Generall pre|sently, or else all the Gold in Cheapside cannot ransome her: wilt thou not stirre when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Shoare listen me, thy wise is mine thats flat,
This night in thine owne house shée sleepes with mee,
Now Crosebie Lord Maior shall we enter in?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Crosebie the Lord Maior tels thée proud rebell no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No Croseby shall I not: then doating Lord,
I cra●e the name of rebell down thy throat,
Theres not the poorest rascall of my campe,
But if he chance to meete thee in Cheapside
Upon thy footcloath, he shall make thee light,
And hold his stirrop while he mount thy horse,
Then lackie him which way he please to goe,
Crosebie●le make the Citizens be glad,
To send thee and the Aldermen thy brethren,
All m●nicled, and chainde like Gally slanes,
To ransome them, and to redéeme the Citie.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Nay then proud ●bel, pause & heare me speak,
Theres not the poorest and meanest Citizen,
That is a faithfull subiect to the King.
But in despight of thy rebellious route,
Shall walke to Bowe, a small wand in his ●d
Although thou lie encamped at M●leend Greene,
And not the proudest rebell of you all,
Shall dare to touch him for his damned soule.
Come, we will pull vp our port●ses,
And let me see thee enter if thou dare.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Spoken like a man, and true Veluet ●acket,
And we will enter or strike by the way.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Lord Mai●r, Recorder, and losseline.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Wheres master Recorder, and master Iosseline?

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.p:
Here my Lord Maior, wee now haue mande the
walles, and fortified such places as were need●ll,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why it is well, brothers and Citizens,
Sticke to your Citie as good men should do,
Thinke that in Richards time euen such a rebell,
Was then by Walworth the L. Maior of London,
Stabd dead in Smithfield:
Then shew your selues as it be fits the time.
And let this find a hundreth Walworth, now,
Dare stabbe a rebell were he made of brasse,
And Prentises sticke to your officers,
For you may come to be as we are now,
God and our King against an arrant rebel,
Brothers away, let vs defend our walles:

sp.speaker: 1. Pren
sp.l: My Lord your words are able to in●use,
A double courage in a cowards breast,
Then feare not vs although our chinnes be bare,
Our hearts are good, the triall shall be séene,
Against these rebels on this champion gréene.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.l: We haue no tricks nor pollices of warre,
But by the ancient custome of our Fathers,
Wéele soundly lay it on, takte off that will.
And London Prentises be rulde by me,
Die ere ye loose faire Londons libertie.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: How now my flatcaps, are you grown so braue?
Tis but your words, whē matters come to proose
Youle scudde as twere a companie of shéepe,
My counsaile therefore is to kéepe your shops,
What lack you, better will bes●em your mouths,
Then termes of warre, in sooth you are too yong:

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sirra go too, you shall not find it so,
Flatcaps thou calst vs, wée scorne not the name,
And shortly by the vertue of our swords,
Wéele make your cap so sit vnto your crowne,
As sconce and cap and all kisse the ground.

sp.speaker: 2. Pr.
sp.l: You are those desperate idle swaggering mates,
That haunt the suburbs in the time of peace,
And raise vp a●-house braules in the stréet,
And when the rumor of the warre begins,
You hide your heads, and are not to be found,
Thou termest it better that we kéepe our shops,
It's good indéed we should haue such a care,
But yet for all our kéeping now and then,
Your Pelfring fingers breake into our lockes,
Vntill at Tyborne you acquite the fault:
Go to, albeit by custome we are milde,
As those that doe professe ciuilitie,
Yet being moude, a nest of angrie hornets
Shall not be more offensi● then we will,
Wéele flie about your eares and sting your hearts.

sp.speaker: Ioss.
sp.l: He tels you truth my friends, and so foorth.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Who can endure to be so vrauce by boyes?

sp.speaker: 1. Pr.
sp.l: Nay scorne vs not that we are Prentises,
The Chronicles of England can report,
What memorable actions we haue done,
To which this daies atchieuement shall be knit,
To make the volume larger then it is.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now of mine honor, yée doe cheare my heart
Braue English ofsprings, valiantly resolude.

sp.speaker: 2. Pre.
sp.l: My Lord returne you backe, let vs alone,
You are our Masters, giue vs leaue to worke,
And if we do not banquish them in fight,
Let vs go supperles to bed at night.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Spicing, Smoke, and their crew.

sp.speaker: Spi. Sm.
sp.p: Get thée vp on the top of S. Buttolphs stéeple, and make a proclamation.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.l: What a plague should I proclaime there?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: That the hels be rung backward,
And cutting of throats be cride hauocke,
No more calling of lanthorne and candlelight,
That maidenheads be valued at iust nothing:
And Sacke be sold by the Sallet.
That no pidling slaue stand to picke a locke, but slash me off the hinges, as one would slit vp a Cowes paunch.

sp.speaker: Spicing.
sp.p: Let no man haue lesse then a warehouse to his wardrope: crie a figge for a Sergeant, and walke by the Counter like a Lord, plucke out the clapper of Bow bell, and hang vp all the Sextons in the Cittie.

sp.speaker: Smoke.
sp.p: Rantam Scantam, Rogues follow your leader, Caualero Spicing the maddest slaue that ere pund spice in a morter.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Take me an Vsurer by the gr●asie pouch, and shake out his Crownes, as a hungrie dog would shake a Haggas, Barre foule play Rogues, and liue by honest silching and stea|ling, he that hath a true finger, let him ●aite his face to the fryingpan.
Follow your Leader Rogues, follow your Leader.

sp.speaker: Smoake.
sp.l: Assault, Assault, and crie a Falconbridge.

div.stage: Iosseline on the walles cries to them.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Sirra Spicing, if Spicing bee thy name, we are here for matters and causes as it might ●me for the King, therefore it were good, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Open the gates, or if we be the picklocks, ye Rogues weele play the Mastiffe dogs amongst you: If I woorie not a thousand of you with my teeth, let mee bee hangde in a packethreed, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Fond fellow, iustice is to be vsed, I marie is it, and law in some sort as it were is to be followed, oh God forbid else, this our Magistrate hath power as might seeme, and soforth, for dutie is to be obserued, and Officers must be obeyed, in sort and calling, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Weele talke more anone, good M. and so forth.

div.stage: Here is a verie fierce assault on all sides, wherein the Pren|tises do great seruice.
Enter Falconbridge angrie with his men.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why this it is to trust to these base Rogues.
This durtie scun● of rascall ●esanirie:
This hartles rout of base rascalitie;
A plague vpon you all, you cowardly Rogues;
You crauand curres, you s●y muddy clownes,
Whose courage but consistes in multitude,
Like shéepe and ●eat that follow one another,
Which if one runne away, all follow after:
This hedge-bred rascal, this filthie frie of ditches,
A vengeance take you all, this t'is to lead you,
Now doe you crie and shrike at euery shocke,
A hot consuming mischiefe follow you.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Swounds scale rogues, scale, a Falconbridge, a Falconbridge.

div.stage: Enter Lord Maior and histraine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Set open the gates, nay then wéel sally out,
It neuer shall be said when I was Maior,
The Londoners were shut vp in the Citie,
Then crie King Edward, and lets vs issue out.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Now if ye be true hearted Englishmen,
The gat'es set open and the portcullise vp:
Lets Pel Mel in, to stop their passage out,
He that first enters, be possest of Cheape,
I giue him it fréely, and the chiefest wench.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: That he can find, let that lie in the bargaine.

div.stage: Exeunt.
The Lord Maior and the Citizens hauing valiantly repulsed the Rebels from the Citie: Enters Falconbridge and Spicing and the● traine wounded and dismaied.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Hear'st thou Generall, theres hote drinking at the mouth of Bishopsgate, for our soldiours are all Mouth, they lie like Rascals with their brains beaten out, therefore since we are all like to féed h●gs in Houndsditch, let vs retire our troupes, and saue our maimed men, or if we issue further, we are put to the sword euery mothers sonne of vs.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Art thou that villaine in whose damned mouth,
Was neuer heard of any word but wounds?
Whose r●rcant limbes are nocht with gaping scarres,
Thicker then any carking craft-mans score,
Whose very skalpe is scracht and crasde and broken,
Like an old mazzer beaten on the stones,
And standest thou now to saue our maimed men?
A plague vpon thee coward.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Why how now base Thomas? Swounds, wert thou a base Viall, thou art but a rascall and a rebell as I am, hea|rest thou, if I do not turne true Su●ed and leaue thee, let me be wooried with dogs, Swounds dost thou impeach my manhood? Tom Neuill thou hadst as good to haue ●nnde thy selfe as vttered such a word, flatly I forsake thee, and all that loue Ned Spicing follow me.

div.stage: Here the rest offer to follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come come yee testic s●le, thou séest me gréende,
Yet canst not beare with mine infirmitie,
Thou knowest I hold thee for as tall a man
As any lines or breathes our English ay●e,
I know there liues not a more fierie spirit,
A more resolued daliant, a plague vpon it,
Thou knowest I loue thée, yet if a word escape
●y lips in anger, how teastie then thou art?
I had rather all men left me then thy selfe,
Thou art my soule, thou art my Genius:
I cannot liue without thee not an hower,
Thus must I still be forc'd against my will,
To sooth this durtic slaue, this cowardly rascall.
Come, come be friends, ye teastie firebrand,
We must retire there is no remedie.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Nay Tom, if thou wilt haue me mount on the walles,
And cast my selfe downe headlong on their pikes,
He doe it, but to impeach my valour,
Had any man but thou spoke halfe so much,
I would haue sp●t his heart, still be ware
My valour, such words go hardly downe,
Well, I am friends, thou thoughtest not as thou spakest.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No on my soule, thou thinkest not that I did,
Sound a retreat there I commaund ye strait,
But whither shall wée retire

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: To Mileend Greene, theres no fitter place.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Then let vs backe retire to Mil●nd Greene,
And there expect fresh succour from our friends,
With such supply as shall ere long assure
The Citic is our owne, march on, away.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the L. Maior with his traine and Prentises.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: Ye haue best●d yée like good Cittizens,
And she wne your selues true subiects to your king,
You worthily p●entise bestirde your selues,
That it did th●re my heart to sée your valour,
The rebels are retirde to M●eerd Greene,

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Where so we may not suffer them to rest.
But issue forth vpon them with fresh force.

sp.speaker: los.
sp.p: My L. Maior, d●gence doth well, and so forth. Matters must be looked into as they ought, indéed should they, when things are well done, they are, and so forth, for causes and things must indeede be look● into.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Well sir, we ver●e well conceiue your meaning,
And you haue ●wne your selfe a worthie gentleman:
See that our wals be kept with courts of guard,
And well defended against the enemie,
For we will now withdraw vs to Guild hall,
To take aduise what further must be don.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Master Shoare and Ianc his wife.

sp.speaker: Shore.
sp.l: Be not afraid (swéet heart) the worst is past,
God haue the praise, the victorie is ours,
We haue preuailde, the rebels are repulsoe,
And euerie str●te of London soundeth ioy,
Canst thou then (gentle Ianc) be sad alone?

sp.speaker: Ianc.
sp.l: I am not sad now you are here with me,
My toy, my hope, my comfort, and my loue,
My déere, déere husband, kindest Mathew shoare,
But when these armes the circles of my soule,
Were in the fight so forward as I heard,
How could I choose, swéet heart, but be afraid?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Why dost thou tremble now, when perilspast●

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I thinke vpon the horror of the tune,
But tell me why you fought so desperately?

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: First to maintaine King Edwards royaltie,
Next to defend the Cities libertic,
But chiefly ●anc to keepe thee from the foyle,
Of him that to my face did how thy spoyle,
Had he prcua●de, where then had béene our liues,
Dishonored our daughters, rauished our faire wiues,
Possest our goods, and set our seruants free,
Yet all this nothing to the losse of thee.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Of mee sweet heart? why how should I be lost?
Were I by thousand stormes of fortune tost?
And should endure the poorest wretched life,
Yet Iane will be thy honest loyall wife,
The greatest Prince the sunne did euer see,
Shall neuer make me proue vntruc to thee:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I feare not faire meanes, but a rebels force,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: These hands shal make this bodie a dead corse,
●re force or flatterie shall mine honour staine,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: True fame sur●iues, when death the ●sh hath slaine.

div.stage: Enter an Officer from the Lord Maior.

sp.speaker: Of.
sp.l: God saue ye maister Shore, and mistris by your leaue,
Sir my L. Maior sends for ye by Maio●,
And prates your speedie presence at Guild hall,
Theres newes the rebels haue made head again,
And haue ensco●de themselues vpon Mileeud,
And prescutly our armed men must out,
You being Captaine of two companies
In honour of your v●lour and your skill,
Must lead the vaward, God & right stand with yee.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Friend tell my Lord ile wait vpon him strait.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Friend tel my Lord he does my husband wrong,
To set him formost in the danger still,
Ye shall not go if I may haue my will,

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Peace wife, no more, friend I wil follow yée,

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I faith ye shall not, prethée do not go.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not go swéet heart? that were a cowards trick,
A traitors part to shrinke when others fight,
Enuie shall neuer say that Mathew Shoare
The Goldsmith ●aid, when other men went out,
To meete his Kings and countries enemie,
No Iane gainst all the rebels on Mileend,
I dare alone K. Edwards right defend.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: If you be slaine, what shall become of mée?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Kight well my w●ch, ●nowe wil marrie thée,
I leaue thee worth at least fiue thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Marrie again. that word my heart doth wound,
Ile neuer marrie, nor I will not liue,
If thou be kild, let me go with thée Mat.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: ●is idle talke good Iane, no more of that,
Go to my Ladie Maioresse and the rest,
As you are still companion with the best,
With them be merrie, and pray for our good speed,

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: To part from thee my very heart doth bléed.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge with his troupes marching, as being at Mileend.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Yet stand we in the sight of v●card Troy,
And sucke the ayre she drawes: our ●erie breath
Flies from our nostrils warme vnto the walles,
We beard her bristling spires, her battled towres,
And proudly stand and g●e her in the sace,
Looke on me, and I doubt not ye imagine,
My worth as great as any one of yours,
My fortunes, would I basely fawne on Edward,
To be as faire as anie mans in England,
But he that kéepes your soueraigne in the Towre,
Hath sea●de my land, and robd me of my right:
I am a Gentleman as well as hee,
What he hath got, he bolds by tyrannie,
Now if you faint, or cowardly should flie,
There is no hope for anie one to liue,
We heare the Londoners will leaue the Citie,
And bid vs battaile here on ●ilcend Greene,
Whom if we vanquish, then we take the towne,
And ride in triumph thorow Cheape to Paules,
The Mint is ours, Cheap, Lumbard stréet our owne
The meanest souldier wealthier then a king.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: March faire ye rogues, all kings or capknitters: dost thou heare Tom Falconbridge? I pre thee grant me one boone I shall aske thee.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: What is it Ned: its hard I should denie thee.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Why that when we haue woune the Crie, as we can|not chuse but winne it, that I may haue the knighting of all these rogues and rascalles.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: What then? Zonnds I scorne your scuruie way mou|thed, what then? now a pore take me it I fight a blow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why this is fine, go to, knight whom thou wilt:

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Who, I knight any of them? Ile sée them hangde first for a companie of tattred ragged rascailes, if I were a king, I would not knight one of them?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: What not mee Caualero Chub?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Yes, I care not if I knight thee: and yet ile see thee hangd ere ile honour thee so much: I care not so much for the matter, but I would not be denide my humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why what a peruerse fellow art thou Ned?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Ho my sine Tom, my braue Falconbridge, my mad Greeke, my lustie Neuill: thou art a king, a Cesar, a plague 〈◊〉 thee, I loue thee not, and yet ile die with thee.

div.stage: Enter the Lord Maior, Recorder, Iosseline, Shoare, and their Souldiours marching.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: See how rebellion can exalt it selfe,
●ing the feathers of sicke discipline.

sp.speaker: Recer.
sp.l: They thinke they can outlooke our tr●r lookes,

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Marke but the scornefull eie of Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I rather thinke tis feare vpon his cheeke,
Decyphers pale disturbance in his heart.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Our comming forth hath, well, I say no more,
But shall we take occasion, and so forth,
Rebellion should haue no respite, oh my Lord,
The time hath ●ene, but all is one for that.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: How like a troupe of ranke oreridden iades,
You hu●se bearded Citizens appeare?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Nay, rather so many men in the Moone,
And euerie one a forzen bush in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: The so● and 〈◊〉 wards? now faire befall them,
Would anie one haue thought before this houre,
There had béene such increase of muddie slaues?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Peace soldsours, they are resolute you sée,
And not to sta● vs, nor fauour them,
Such haughtie sto●hs seldome haue béene séene,
Imbodied in the breasts of Cittizens,
How sternly in their owne peculiar strength,
Without the assistance of their lingring king,
Did they of late repulse vs from their walles?
And now againe how expeditiously,
And vnexpected they haue met vs here?
Were we more deadly incensed then we are,
I would not but commend their chiualrie.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Captaine, shall we go challenge them to fight?
Sbloud we burne daylight, theile thinke anon,
We are afraid to sée their glittering swords.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Tell them they come in stéed of pudding pies,
And Stratford cakes to makes a banquet here.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Soft giue me leaue, I will deuise with words,
To weaken and abash their fortitude,

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: The bastard offers to come forth my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I am the man intend to answere him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Crosbie.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Traytor.

sp.speaker: all
sp.l: Traitour? zounds downe with him.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Be patient, giue me leaue I say to speake,
I doubt not but the traitors name shall rest
With those that keeps their lawfull K. in bonds:
Meane time ye men of London once againe,
Behold my warlike colours are displaide,
Which I haue vowd shal neuer be wrapt vp,
Untill your loftie buildings kisse our féet,
Unles you grant me passagethrough your stréets.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Passage, saist thou? that must be ore our breasts,
If any passage thou art like to haue.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Why then vpon your bodies will I tread,
And wade through standing pooles of your lost bloud.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: We know thy threats, and reckon them as wind,
Not of suffecient powre to shake a reede.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: But we shooke your gates not long agoe,
And made your walles to shake like yrish bogges.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: I, and so terrified ye, that not one of ye ●rst come to fetch a pinte of sacke at the mouth at Bishopsgate, no not for your lines.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: I but you know what followed, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Etretera? are you there? mee thinks the sight of the dun Bull, the Neuels honored crest, should make you leaue your broken sentences, and quite forget euer to speake at all.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: Nay then looke thou vpon our Citties armes.
Wherein is a bloudie dagger, that is it,
Where with a rebell like to Falconbridge,
Had his desert, meete for his trecherie,
Can you behold that, and not quake for feare?

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Since when, it is successfuely decreed,
Traitors with vs shall neuer better speede.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Captaine and fellow soldiers talke no more,
But draw your meaning forth in down right blows.

sp.speaker: Falcon.
sp.l: Sound then alarum.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: Do the like for vs, and where the right is, there attend successe.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Stay and be better aduisde, why countr●,
What is this Falconbridge you follow so?
I could instruct you, but you know my mind.
And Falconbridge what are these rusticalles,
Thou shouldst repose such confidense in glasse,
Shal I informe thee? no, thou art wise inough,
Edward of Yorke delaies the time you say,
Therefore hée will not come, imagine so,
The Citties weake, hold that opinion still,
And your pretence King Henries libertie.
True, but as how? shall I declare you? no.
What thē? youle fight, a gods name take your choise,
I canno more but giue you mine aduise.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away with this parentheses of words,
Crosbie courage thy men, and on this greene,
Whose cause is right, let it be quickly séene.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.l: I am as readic as thou canst desire,
On then a Gods name.

div.stage: They fight, the rebels driue them backe: then Enter Falconbridge and Spicing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This was well fought, now Spicing list to me.
The Cittizens thus hauing giuen vs ground,
And therefore somewhat daunted, take a band
Of Essex souldiours, and with all the spéede
Thou possibly canst make, withdraw thy selfe,
And get between the Cittie gates and them.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Oh braue Tom Neuill, gallant Falconbridge,
Ayme at thy intended pollicie,
This is thy meaning, while thou art imploide,
And holdst them battaile here on Mileend Greene,
I must prouide as harbenger before,
There be not onely cleere and open passage,
But the best marchants houses to receiue
Vs and our retinew, I am proud of that,
And will not sléepe vpon thy iust commaund.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away then I will follow as I may,
And doubt not but that ours will be the day.

div.stage: After some excursions, enter Lord Maior and Master Shoare.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: We haue recouered what before we lost,
And heauen stands with the iustice of our cause,
But this I noted in the fight euen now,
That part of this rebellious crew is sent,
By what direction, or for what intent,
I cannot ghesse, but may suspect the worst,
And as it séemes, they compasse it about,
To hemme vs in, or get the gate of vs,
And therefore Cosin Shoare, as I repose
Trust in thy valour and thy loyaltie,
Draw forth thrée hundred ●wmen, and some pikes,
And presently encounter their assault.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.l: I haue your meaning, and effect my Lord,
I trust shall disappoint them of their hope.

div.stage: After an alarum, Enter Spicing with a drum and certaine Soldiours.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Come on my harts, we will be kings to night,
Carouse in Gold, and sléepe with marchants wiues,
While their poore husbands loose their liues abroad,
We are now quite behind our enemies backs,
And theres no let or hindrance in the way,
But we may take possession of the towne,
Ah you mad rogues, this is the wished houre,
Follow your leader, and be resolute.

div.stage: As he marcheth, thinking to enter, Shoare and his souldiours issue forth and repulse him, after excursions, wherein the rebels are disperst. Enter Maior, Reco. Shoa. Iosseline, and a Messenger talking with the Maior.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I, my good friend, so certifie his grace,
The Rebels are dispersed all and fled,
And now his Highnes méetes with victorie.
Marshall your sclues, and kéepe in good aray:
To adde more glorie to this victorie:
The King in person commeth to this place,
How great an honour haue you gainde to day?
And how much is this Citie famde for euer,
That twise without the helpe, eyther of King,
Or any, but of God, and our owne selues,
We haue preuailde against our countries foes?
Thankes to his maiestie assisted vs,
Who alwaies helps true subiects in their néed.

div.stage: The Trumpets sound, then enters king Edward, L. How. Sellenger and the traine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where is my Lord Maior?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Here dread Soueraigne.
I hold no Lordship nor no dignitie,
In presence of my gracious Lord the King,
But all I humble at your highnes féete,
With the most happie conquest of proud rebels,
Dispearst and fled, that now remaines no doubt,
Of euer making head to vexe vs more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You haue not ●ane the bastard Falconbridge:
Or is he slaine?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Neither my gracious Lord.
Although we labourd to our vttermost,
Yet all our care came ouer short,
For apprehending him or Spicing eyther
But some are taken, others on proffered grace
Yéelded themselues, and at your mercie stand.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thanks good L. Maior, you may condemne vs
Of too much slacknes in such vrgent néed:
But we assure you on our royall word,
So soone as we had gathered vs a power,
We dallied not, but mane all hast we could,
What order haue ye tane for Falconbridge,
And his confederates in this rebellion?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Vnder your leaue my Liedge, we haue proclaimd
Who bringeth Falconbridge aliue or dead,
Shall be requited with a thousand markes,
As much for Spicing, others of lesse worth
At easier rates are set.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Well haue ye done,
And wee will see it paid from our Erchequer.
Now leaue we this and come to you,
That haue so well veserude in these affaires,
Affaires, I meane of so maine consequence.
Kneele downe and all of you receiue in field,
The honor you haue merited in field.
sp.stage: There he drawes his sword and knights them.
sp.l: Arise Sir Iohn Crosbie, L. Maior of London & Knight.
Arise vp Sir Ralph Iosseline knight.
Arise Sir Thomas Vrswicke our Recorder of London, and Knight.
Now tell me which is M. Shoare.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This same my Lord,
And hand to hand he fought with Falconbridge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shoare knéele thou downe.
What call yée else his name?

sp.speaker: Recor.
sp.l: His name is Mathew Shoare my Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Shoare, why kneelest thou not, and at thy Souetaignes hand receiue thy right?

sp.speaker: Shoare.
sp.l: Pardon me gracious Lord,
I do not stand contemptuous or des●ising
Such royall fauour of my Soueraigne,
But to acknowledge mine vnworthines:
Farre be it from the thought of Mathew Shoare,
That he should be aduanc'de with Aldermen,
With our L. Maior, & our right grane Recorder.
If any thing hath béene performde by me,
That may deserue your Highnes mean'st respect,
I haue inough, and I desire no more.
Then let me craue that I may haue no more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well, be it as thou wilt, some other way
We will deuise to quittance thy deserts,
And not to faile therein vpon my word.
Now let me tell ye all my friends at once,
Your King is married, since you saw him last,
And haste to helpe you in this néedfull time,
Made me on sudden to forsake my bride.
But séeing all things are fallen out so well,
And there remaines no further doubt of ill,
Let me ●ntreate you would goe boote your selues,
And bring your King a little on his way.
How say you my Lord, shall it be so?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now God forbid but that my Lord the King
Should alwaies haue his Subiects at command.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.p: Forbid quotha? I in good sadnes, your maie|stie shall finde vs alwaies readie, and so forth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why then set forward Gentlemen,
And come L. Maior, I must conferre with you.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Falconbridge and spicing with their wea|pons in their hands.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Art thou the man whose victories drawn at sea,
Fild cuerie heart with terror of thy name?
Art thou that Neuill whom we tooke thee for?
Thou art a lowse, thou bastard Falconbridge?
Thou baser then a bastard, in whose birth
The very dregs of seruitude appeares,
Why tell me, liuer of some rotten shéepe,
After by thy allurements we are brought,
To vndertake this course, after thy promises
Of many golden mountaines to eusue,
Is this the greatest comfort thou canst glu●?
Hast thou insnarde our héedles feet with death,
And brought vs to the Jebbet of defame,
And now do'st bid vs shift and saue our selues?
No crauen were I sure I should be tane,
I would not stirre my feete, vntill this hand
Had venged me on thee for misguiding vs.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Opprobrious villaine, stable excrement,
That neuer dreamst of other manhood yet,
But how to ierke a horse, vntill my words
Insusde into thee resolutions sire.
Controlst thou me for that wherein thy selfe,
Art onely the occasion of mishap?
Hadst thou and they stood to it as well as I,
The day had beene our owne, and London now,
That laughes in triumph, should haue wept in teares,
But being backt by such faint harted slaues
No marualle if the Lion go to wracke,
As though it were not incident to Kings,
Sometime to take repulse, mine is no more:
Nor is not for that muddie braine of thine
To tutor me how to digest my losse,
Then flie with those that are alreadie fled,
Or stay behind, and hang all but the head.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Oh preiudice to Spicings conquering name,
Whose valor euen the hacks this sword has made
Vpon the flint, and yron barres at Aldgate:
Like mouthes wil publish whiles the City stands
That I shrunke backe● that I was neuer seene
To shew my manly spleene, but with a whipe.
I tell thee Falconbridge the least of these,
Do challenge bloud before they be appeasde,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Away ye scoundrell, tempt not my resolue,
The courage that sur●es in Falconbridge,
Scornes the incounter of so base a drudge.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: By the pure temper of this sword of mine,
By this true flesh and bloud that gripes the same,
And by the honour I did winne of late,
Against those frostie bearded Citizens,
It shall be tride before we do depart,
Whether accuseth other wrongfully,
Or which of vs two is the better man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I shall but quit the Hangman of a labour,
Yet rather then to be ●pbraided thus,
The Eagle once will stoope to féede on tarrion.

div.stage: They fight, Enter Chub.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.p: Hold if ye be men, if not, hold as ye are: rebels & 〈◊〉 théeues: I bring you newes of a proclamation, the King hath promised that whosoeuer can bring the head of Falconbridge, or Spicing, shal haue for his labour a thousand crownes, what meane you then to swagger? saue your selues.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: This proclamation comes in happie time,
Ile banquish Falconbridge, and with this sword
Cut off his head, and beare it to the King,
So not alone shall I be pardoned,
But haue the thousand crownes is promised.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This rascall was ordainde to saue my life,
For now when I haue ouerthrowne the wretch,
Euen with his head ●le yéeld me to the King,
His princely word is past to pardon mee,
And though I were the chiefe in this rebellion,
Yet this will be a meanes to make my peace.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: Oh that I knew how to betray them both.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: How saist thou Spi. wilt thou yéeld thy selfe?
For I haue vowde eyther aliue or dead
To bring thee to King Edward?

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: And I haue vowde the like by thee.
How will these two bad contarie●s agree?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: And I the same by both of you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come sir, ile quickly c●d you of that care.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: And what thou lottest me, shall be thy share.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Here comes a miller, helpe to part the fray,
These are the rebels Falconbridge and Spicing,
The worst of them is worth a thousand crownes.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Marrie and such a bootic should I haue,
Submit, submit, it is in vaine to striue,

div.stage: Exit Fal.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Why what art thou:

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: One that will hamper yon,
But whats the other that is fled away?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Oh miller, that was Falconbridge,
And this is Spicing his companion.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: I tell thée miller thou hast béene the meanes,
To hinder the most charitable déed,
What euer honest Christian vndertooke.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Thou canst beare nie witnesse I had fane
That most notorious rebell but for him.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But I haue taken thée, and the world knowes,
That Spicing is as bad as who is best.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Why thou mistakst, I am a true subsect.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Miller hée lies, be sure to hold him fast.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Dost thou accuse me? apprehend him too,
For hees as guiltie as any of vs.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: Come you shall both togither answere it,
Before my Lord Maior, and here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Lord Maior, Iosseline, and other attendants.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Sir Ralph Iosseline, haue you euer séen a Prince more a●|sable then Edward is? what merry talke he had vpon the way.

sp.speaker: Ios.
sp.l: Doubtlesse my Lord héeie prooue a royal King.
But how now what are these?

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: God saue your honour,
Here I present vnto you my Lord Maior,
A paire of rebels, whom I did espie
As I was busie grinding at my mill,
And taking them for vagrant idle k●ucs,
That had beset some trueman from his house,
I came to kéepe the peace, but afterward,
Found that it was the bastard Falconbridge,
And this his mate together by the eares,
The one, for all that I could doo, escapte,
The other standeth at your mercie here.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It is the rebell Spicing.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: It is indeed?
I see you are not blind, you know mee then.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Wel miller, thou hast done a subic●s part,
And worthily deserust that recompence
Is publikely proclaimed by the King,
But whats this other? I haue séene his face,
And as I take it, he is one of them.

sp.speaker: Mill.
sp.l: I must confesse, I tooke them both togither,
●ee ayded me to apprehend the rest.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: A telles you true my Lord, I am Chub the Chaundler, and I curse the time that euer I saw their faces, for if they had not been, I had liude an honest man in mine own countrie, and neuer come to this,

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Out rogue, dost thou recant for feare of death?
I Ma●or, I am he that sought to cut your thrpate,
And since I haue miscaried in the fact,
Ile néere denie it, do the worst you can.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Bring him a way, he shall haue martiall law, and at the next tree we do come vnto,
Be hangde to rid the world of such a wretch.
Miller thy dutie is a thousand markes,
Which must be sharde bet wixt thée and this poore fel|low, that did reueale him. And sirra, your life is saude on this condition, that you hang vp Spicing, how saist thou, wilt thou do it?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Will I doe it? what a question is that?
I would hang him if he were my father to saue mine own life.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Then when yée haue done it, come home to my house, and there ve truly shall haue your reward.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.l: Well sirra, then thou must be my hangman?

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: I by my troth sir, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Well, commend me to little Pim, and pray her to re|d●me my pande hose, they lie at the blew Bore for eleuen pence, and if my hostesse wil haue the other odde penie, tell her she is a damned bawde, and there is no truth in her score.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.p: Take no thought sir for your pande hose, they are lowsie, and not worth the redéeming.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: There is a Constable stickes in my minde, he got my sword from me, that night I should haue killed blacke Ralph, if I had ●ude, I would haue béene meete with him.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: I sir, but heres a thing shall take an order for that.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Cemmend me to blacke Luce, bouncing Besse, & lustie ●ate, and the other pretie morsels of mans flesh. Farewell Pinke and Pinnesse, ●libote, and Caruell, Turnbuil, and Spittle, I die like a man.

sp.speaker: Chub.
sp.l: Oh Captaine Spicing, thy vaine inticing, brought me from my trade,
From good candles making, to this paines taking, a rebell to be made,
Therefore Ned Spicicing, to quit thy enticing, this must be th● hope,
By one of thy fellowes, to be led to the Gallowes, to end in a rope.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Hobs the Tanner of Tamworth:

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
Dudgeon, dost thou he are, looke well to Brocke my mare, driue Dunne and her faire and softly downe the hill, and take héede the thornes teare not the hornes of my Cow hides, as thou goest neere the hedges: ha what saist thou knaue? is the Bulles hide downe? why lay it vp again, what rare I? He meete thee at the stile, and helpe to set all straight. And yet God helpe, its a crooked world, and an vnthriftie, for some that haue nere a shooe, had rather go barefoote, then buy clo●-leather to mend the old, when they can buy no new, for they haue time inough to mend all, they sit so long betweene the cup and the wall, well God amend them, God amende them. Let me see by my executor heere, my leather pouch,
what I haue taken, what I haue spent, what I haue gained. what I haue lost, & what I haue laid cut: my taking is more thē my spending, for heres store left. I haue spent but a groat, a penie for my two iades, a penie to the poore, a penie pot of ale, and a penie cake for my man and me, a dicker of Cowe|hides cost mee.
sp.stage: Here enter the Queene & Duchesse with their riding rods, vnpinning their masks, Hobs goes forward.
sp.p: Snailes who comes here? mistris Ferries, or mistris what call ye her? Put vp Iohn Hobs, money tempts beauty.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Well met good fellow, sawest thou not the hart?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My heart? God blesse me from séeing my heart.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thy heart? the déereman, we demaund the decre.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Do you demaund whats déere? mary corne and cow hides, Masse a good sni●g lasse, well like my daughter Nell, I had rather then a bend of leather shee and I might smutch to|gither.

sp.speaker: Dutchesse.
sp.l: Camst thou not downe the wood?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Yes mistris that I did.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And sawst thou not the déere imbost?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: By my hood ye make me laugh, what the dickens is it loue that makes ye prate to me so fondly, by my fathers soule I would I had iobd faces with you.

sp.speaker: Huntsm.
sp.p: Why how now Hobs, so saucie with the Dutchesse and the Quéene?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Much Queene I trow, these be but women, and one of them is like my wench, I would she had her rags, I would giue a load of haire and hornes, and a fat of leather, to match her to some iustice, by the meghollie.

sp.speaker: 2. Huntsm.
sp.l: Be silent Tanner, and aske pardon of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: And ye be the Queene, I crie ye mercie good mistris Queene.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No fault my friend, Madam lets take our bowes,
And in the standing seeke to get a shoote.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Come bende our bowes, and bring the herde of d●re.

div.stage: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: God send yée-good standing, and good striking, and fat flesh, sée if all Gentle women be not alike when their blacke facce be on, I tooke the Quéene, as I am true Tanner, for mistris Ferris.

div.stage: Enter Sellenger and Howard in Greene.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Soft, who comes here, more knaues yet?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ho good fellow, saw● thou not the King?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: No good fellow, I saw no King, which King doost thou aske for.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Why King Edward, what King is there else?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Theres another King and ye could hit on him, one Harrie, one Harrie, and by our Ladie they say, hees the honester man of the two.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sirra beware you speake not treason.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: What if I doe?

sp.speaker: Sell.
sp.l: Then thoult be hangde.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: A dogs death, ●le not meddle with it, for by my troth I know not when I speake treason, when I do not, theres such halting betwirt two Kings, that a man cannot goe vp|right, but he shal offend tone of them, I would God had them both for me.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: Well, thou sawst not the King?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No, is he in the countrie?

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: ●es hunting here at Drayton Basset.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: The deuill he is, God blesse his Mastership: I saw a woman here that they said was the Quéene, shees as like my daughter, but my daughter is the fairer, as euer I sée.

sp.speaker: Sell.
sp.l: Fare well fellow, speake well of the King,

div.stage: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: God make him an honest man, I hope thats well spo|ken, for byth mouse foot, some giue him hard words, whether be ●rues vm or not, let him looke to that, ile meddle of my cow hide, and let the world slide.

The diuell in a dung cart, how these roysters swarme in the ●trie now the King is so neere? God liuer me from this, for this 〈◊〉 like a ●heese, but a man cannot tell amongst
these Courtnoles whose true.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: ●olla my friend, good fellow pre thée stay.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: No such matter, I haue more haste of my way.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: If thou be a good fellow, let me borrow a word.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: My purse thou meanest, I am no good fellow, and I pray God thou beest not one.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Why? dost thou not loue a good fellow?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: No, good fellowes be theeues.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Dost thou thinke I am one?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Thought is frée, and thou art not my ghostly father.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: I meane thée no harme.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Who knowes that but thy selfe? I pray God he spie not my purse.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: On my troth I meane shee none.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Upon thy oth ile stay: now, what saist thou to me? Speake quickly, for my companie staies for me beneath at the next stile.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: The King is hunting hereabouts, didst thou see his Maiestie?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: His maiestie, whats that? his horse, or his mare?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Tush, I meane his Grace.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Grace quotha? pray God he haue any: which King dost thou quire for?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: Why for King Edward, knowst thou anie more Kings then one?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I know not so many, for I tel thee I know none, mar|rie I heare of King Edward.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Didst thou see his Highnesse?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: By my hollida●e, thats the best tearme thou gaust him yet, hees high inough, but hee has put poore King Harrie low inough.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: How low hath he put him?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot tel, but he has put him down, for he has got the crowne, much good doot him with it.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Amen, I like thy talk so wel, I would I knew thy name.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Dost thou not know mee?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Then thou knowest no bodie: didst neuer heare of Iohn Hobs the Tanner of ●am worth?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Not till now I promise thee, but now I like thee wel.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: So do not I thee, I feare thou art some out-rider, that liues by taking of purses here on Basse●s heath, but I feare thée n●t, for I haue wared all my money in Cowhides, at Colesill market, and my man & my mare are hard by at the hill foote.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: ●s that thy grey mare thats tide at the stile with the h●es on her backe':

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Thats Brocke my mare, and theres Dunne my nag, and Dadgeon my man.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Theres neither man nor horse, but onely one mare.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Gods bl●w budkin, has the knaue serud me so? farewel, 〈◊〉 may loose h●s, horns, and mare & all, by prating with thee.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: ●arry man, tarry, th●le sooner take my gelding then thy grav mare, for I ●ue tide mine by her.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: That will I see afore ile take your word.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: Il● beare thée companie.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: I had as lieue go alone:

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter the two huntsmen againe with the Bowes.

sp.speaker: 1 Hunts.
sp.l: ●ow on my troth the Queene shoots passing wel.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: So did the Dutchesse when she was as young.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.l: Age s●s the hand, and shoots both wide & short:

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: What haue they giuen vs?

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.l: S●re rose nobles lust:

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: The Queene gaue foure.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.l: True, and the Dutchesse twaine.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunts.
sp.l: O were we euer so paide for our paine.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunts.
sp.p: ●ut, had the King come, as they said he would, he 〈◊〉 haue ra●de vpon vs showres of gold.

sp.speaker: 2 Hunts.
sp.p: Why he is hunting some where here about, lets first go drinke, and then go seeke him out.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter King Edward againe, and Hobs.

sp.speaker: K. Ed
sp.p: How ●st thou Tanner, wilt thou take my cour● s●t for thy mare?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Courser callst thou him? so ill mought I fare, thy skittish iade will neuer abide, to carry my lether, my hornes nor hide. But if I were so mad to scorce, what boote wouldst thou giue nice?

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.l: May boote, thats boote woorthie, I looke for boot of thée.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Ha, ha, a merrie Iigge, why man, Brocke my mare knowes ha and ree, and will stand when I crie ho, and let me get vp and downe, and make water when I doe.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Ile giue thee a Noble if I like her pace, lay thy Cow|bides in my saddle, and lets iog towards Drayton.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: It's out of my way, but I begin to like thee well.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thou wilt like me better before we doe part,
I pray thée tell ●ee, what say they of the King?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Of the kings thou mean'st, art thou no blab if I tel thée.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: If the King know't not now, hee shall neuer know it for mee.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Masse they say King Harrie's a very aduowtrie man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A ●uout man, and whats King Edward?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Hees a franke franion, a merr● companion, and loues a wench well, they say he has married a poore widdow because shecs faire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dol● thou like him the worse for that?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: No by my feckens, but the better, for though I bee a pla● Tanner, I loue a faire lasse my selfe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prée thee tell mee, how loue they King Edward?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Faith as poore folks loue hollidaies, glad to haue them now and then, but to haue them come too often, will vnd● them, so to sée the king now and then ti's comfort, but euerse day would begger vs, and I may to thée, we feare wée shalbe troubled to lend him no money, for we doubt hees but néedie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Wouldst thou lend him no money if he should neede?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: By my hallidome yes, he shall haue halfe my st●, and ile ●ell sole leather to helpe him to more.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Faith whether louest thou better Harry or Edward.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.l: Nay, thats coúnsel, & two may kéep it, if one be a way.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Shal I say my conscience? I think Harry is the true king.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Art ad●isde of that? Harrie's of the old house of Lan|casber, and that progenitie do I loue.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And thou dost not hate the house of Yorke?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Why no, for I am ●ust a kin to Sutton Wind-mill, I can grinde which way so ere the wind blow, if it bee Harrie I can say wel fare Lancaster, if it be Edward I can sing, Yorke, Yorke for my monse.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.p: Thou art of my mind, but I say Harrie●s the law|full King, Edward is but an vsurper, and a foole and a co|ward.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Nay there thou lyest, he has wit inough, and courage inough, do● thou not speake treason?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I, but I know to whom I speake it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Dost thou? well if I were Constable, I shoulde be forsworne if I set the● not in the stockes for it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well let it go no further, for I did serue King Harrie and I loue him best, though now I serue King Edward.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Thou art the arranter knaue to speake ill of thy ma●|ster, but sirra whats thy name, what office hast thou? and what will the King doe for thee?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My name is Ned, I am the Kings Butler, and he wil do more for me, then for any Noble man in the Court.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: The d●uel he wil, hees the more foole, and so ile tel him, if ere I see him, & I wouid I might sée him in my poore house at Tamworth.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Go with me to the Court and ile bring thée to the king, & what sute so ere thou haue to him, the warrant thée to speede

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I ha nothing to do at Court, ile home with my cowhids, and if the King will come to me he shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Hast thou no sute touching thy trade, to transport hides or sell leather onely in a certaine circuite, or about Barke, or such like, to haue letters pattents?

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p:
By the Masse and the Mattens I like not those Pat|tents, sirra they that haue them, doe as the Priests did in old ●ne, buy and sell the sinnes of the people, so they make the King belée● they mend whats amisse, and for money they
make the thing worse then it is, theres another thing in 〈◊〉, the mor is the pitie?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What pittie Iohn Hobs? I prée thée say all.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Faith ti's pittie that one subica should haue in his hand that might do good to many through the land.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Satcst thou me so ●anner well lets cast lots whether thou shalt go with me to Drayton, or I go home with th●e to Tamworth.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: Lot me no lotting, ile not goe with thee, if thou wilt go with me, cause thart my Lciges man (and yet I thinke bee has many honester) thou shalt bee welcome to Iohn Hobs, thou shalt be welcome to ●ese and bacon, and perhaps a bag|pudding, and my daughter Nell shall pop a possell vpon thee when thou gost to bed.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: Heres my hand, ile but go & see the King seru'de, and ●le be at home as soone as thy selfe.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Dost thou heare me Ned? if I shall be thy host,
Make haste thou art best, for feare thou kisse the ●ost.

div.stage: Exit, Hobs.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Farewell Iohn Hobs, the honest true Tanner
I see plaine men by obseruation,
Of things that alter in the chaunge of times,
Doghter knowledge, and the meanest life,
Proporrioned with content sufficiencie,
Is mericr then the mightie state of Kings.
Now now? what newes bring ye sirs,
Wheres the Quoene?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Her Highnes and your mother my dread Lord,
Are both inuited by Sir Humphrey Bowes,
Where they entend to feast and lodge this night,
And do expect your Graces presence there.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Tom Sellinger I haue other busines;
Astray from you and all my other traine,
I met a Tanner, such a merrie mate,
So frolicke, and so full of good conceit,
That I haue giuen my word to be his guest,
Because he knowes me not to be the King:
Good Cosen Howard grudge not at the lest,
But greete my mother and my wife from mee,
Bid them be merrie, I must haue my humor,
Let them both sup and sléepe when they see time,
Commend me kindly to Sir Humphrey Bowes,
Tell him at breakefast I will visite him.
This night Tom Sellinger and I must feast
With Hobs the Tanner, there plaine Ned & Tom.
No King nor Sellinger for a thousand pound.

div.stage: Enter a Messenger booted with letters, and kneeling giues them to the King.

sp.speaker: How.
sp.l: The Queen & Dutches will be discontent,
Because his ●ighnes comes not to the feast.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir Humphrey Bowes may take the most conceit,
But whats the end, the King will haue his pleasure?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Good newes my boyes, Harrie the sixt is dead, peruse that letter: sirra, drinke you that, giues his purse, and stay not but poste backe againe for life, and thanke my brother Gloster for his newes, commende me to him, ile see him to morrow night. How like yée it sirs?

div.stage: Exit Messenger.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: O passing well my Liege, you may be merrie for these happie newes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The merrier with our host the Tanner Tom,
My Lord take you that letter to the Ladies,
Bidde them be merrie with that second course,
And if wee see them not before wee goe,
Pray them to iourney easily after vs,
Wéele post to London, so good night my Lord.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Hobs and his daughter Nell.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Come Nell, come daughter, is your hands and your face washed?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: I forsooth Father.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Yee must bee cleanely I tell yee, for there comes a Courtnole hither to night, the kings master ships Butler, Ned, a spruce youth, but beware ye be not in loue nor ouer|taken
by him, for Courtiers be slipperie lads.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: No forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Gods blessing on thee, that halfe yéeres schooling at Liechfield, was better to thee then house and land, it has put such manners into thee, I forsooth and no forsooth at euerie word, yee haue a cleane smocke on. I like your apparrel well, is supper readie?

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: I forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Haue wee a good barley bagpudding, a péece of fat Bacon, a good cow heele, a hard cheese, and a browne loafe.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: All this forsooth, and more, yee shall haue a posset, but indeed the rats haue spoyled your hard cheese.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Now the dtuell choake them, so they haue eate mee a farthing candle the other night.

sp.speaker: Dudgeon within.
sp.l: What maister maister.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: How now knaue, what faist thou Dudgeon?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.l: Heres guests come, wheres Hellen?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: What guests be they?

sp.speaker: Dud.
sp.p: A courtnole, one Ned the kings Butcher he sapes, and his friends too.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Ned the kings butcher? ha, ha, the kings butler, take their horses, and walke them, and bid them come neare house, Nell lay the cloth, and clap supper oth b●rd.
Mas heres Ned indeed and another misproud ●uffian,
Welcome Ned, I like thy honestie, thou keepest promise.

sp.speaker: K. Ed.
sp.p: I faith honest Tanner, ile euer keep promise with thée, pre thee bid my friend welcome.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: By my troth ye are both welcome to Tamwoorth: friend I know not your name.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My name is Tom Twist?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Beleeue ye that list: but ye are welcome both, and I like you both well but for one thing.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Nay that I keepe to my selfe, for I sigh to see and thinke, that pride brings many one to er●ion.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pre thee tell v● thy meaning.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Troth I doubt ye nere came truly by all these gay ragges. Tis not your bare wages and thinne f●s yee haue of the King, can keepe ye thus fine, but eyther yee must rob the King priuily, or his subiectes openly, to maintaine your probicallitie.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Thinkest thou so Tanner:

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: Tis no matter what I thinke, come lets go to supper,
What Nell, what Dudgeon, where be these folkes?
sp.stage: Enter Nell and Dudgeon, with a Table couered.
sp.l: Daughter bid my friends welcome.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.l: Ye are welcome Gentlemen as I may say.

sp.speaker: Sell.
sp.l: I thanke yee faire maid.

div.stage: kisse her both.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A prettie wench be my faye.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.l: How likest her Ned?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I like her so well, I would yee would make mée your sonne in law.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: And I like thée so well Ned, that hadst thou an occu|pation, for seruice is no heritage, a young courtier, an olde begger, I could sinde in my heart to cast her away vpon thée, and if thou wilt forsake the court and turne La●ner, or vind thy selfe to a shoomaker in Liechfield,●le giue thee twentie nobles readie money, with my Nell, and trust thée with a dic|ker of leather, to set vp thy trade.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Ned he offers ye saire, if ye haue the grace to take it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He does indeed, Tom, and hereafter ile tell him more.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Come sit downe to supper: go to Nell, no more sheeps eies, ye may be caught I tell ye, these be licorish lads.

sp.speaker: Nell.
sp.p: I warrant ye father, yet in truth Ned is a very proper man, and tother may serue, but Neds a pearle in mine eye.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Daughter, cal Dudgeon and his fellowes, weele haue a thrée men song, to make our guests merrie.
Nailes what courtnoles are yee? yéele neither talke nor cate, What newes at the court? do somewhat for your meat.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Heauie newes there, King Henrie is dead.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Thats light newes & merie for your master king Edward.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But how will the commons take it?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Well, God be with good King Henrie, faith the com|mons will take it as a common thing, deaths an bonest man, for he spares not the King: for as one comes, anothers taue away, and seldome comes the better, thats all we say.

sp.speaker: Sellin.
sp.l: Shrewdly spoken Tanner by my faye.

sp.speaker: Hob.
